The IRS is open—fast-track your refund
**********
Sign in
 
The IRS is open—fast-track your refund
**********
Sign in
 
Your W-2 is being delivered
IRS is accepting returns
Claim your refund today!
The IRS is now accepting returns. File now and put money in your pocket as soon 
as today.
 
**********
Get your max refund
The IRS reported an impact to certain filers' refunds till March 3rd. 
Learn more >
 
Get your refund faster, 
guaranteed
¹
Get your refund 5 days before 
IRS delivery in your chosen 
bank account.²
 
5 days before IRS delivery to your bank account for a fee. Terms apply.
Get fast money
 
Track your refund
Once you file, we’ll tell you when to expect your refund and alert you when it lands in your 
bank account.
 
Start filing now
 
 
 
We're looking out for you
 
We’ll never ask for personal information in an email. When you click on a link, the address should always contain 
“intuit.com/”
. 
*Average Refund Amount: Sum of $3,207 is the average refund American taxpayers received based upon IRS data date ending 2/16/24 and may not reflect actual refund amount received. 
You may be able to receive your federal refund early through your bank, credit union or other financial institution. Terms, fees, and delivery dates may vary. Check with your financial institution for details. 
Money movement services are provided by Intuit Payments Inc., licensed as a Money Transmitter by the New York State Department of Financial Services. For more information about Intuit Payments' money transmission licenses, please visit 
https://www.intuit.com/legal/licenses/payment-licenses/
. 
1 If your federal refund is deposited into your selected bank account less than 5 days before the IRS refund settlement date (the date it would have arrived if sent from the IRS directly), then you will not pay the 5 Days Early fee. See 
Terms of Service
 for more details. 
2 5 Days Early to Your Bank Account: Personal taxes only. Your federal tax refund will be deposited to your selected bank account 5 days before the refund settlement date provided by the IRS (the date your refund would have arrived if sent from the IRS directly). The receipt of your refund 5 Days Early is subject to IRS submitting refund information to us at least 5 days before the refund settlement date. IRS does not always provide refund settlement information 5 days early. You will not be eligible to receive your refund 5 Days Early if (1) you take a Refund Advance loan, (2) IRS delays payment of your refund, or (3) your bank’s policies do not allow for same-day payment processing. 5 Days Early fee will be deducted directly from your refund prior to being deposited to your bank account. If your refund cannot be delivered 5 Days Early, you will not be charged the 5 Days Early fee. 5 Days Early program may change or be discontinued at any time. 
Click here
 to see TurboTax product guarantees, disclaimers and other important information.

Switch & save with our Full Service experts
**********
Sign in
 
Switch & save with our Full Service experts
**********
Sign in
 
Limited time offer
Simply tell us what you paid your tax pro last season—we'll beat it
Sign up today to save at least 10% off* the price you paid your tax pro last tax season. We’ll get your best tax outcome, 100% accuracy 
guaranteed
.
 
Claim offer today
Must lock in by 
3/18 & file by 3/25.
Click for full details
.
 
Switching is easy, 
and so worth it.
 
With this offer, know what you'll pay before your expert files 
your taxes.
 
Specialized experts for your unique 
tax situation.
 
Every dollar you deserve, 100% 
accuracy 
guaranteed
.
 
Switch and save
 
 
 
We're looking out for you
 
We’ll never ask for personal information in an email. When you click on a link, the address should always contain 
“intuit.com/”
. 
*Offer applies to the cost of TurboTax Full Service (“Full Service”) for 
2024
 personal taxes filed in calendar year 2025 and no other services. To be eligible to participate in the Beat the Price Program (“Program”), customer must: (i) Have used a Certified Public Accountant or other licensed tax preparer to prepare, sign and file their 
2023
 personal tax return (including through Full Service and TurboTax Verified Pros but excluding TurboTax Full Service Business); (2) Sign-up for or sign-into TurboTax Full Service and lock in their discount by 
March 18, 2025;
 and (3) File 2024 personal taxes with Full Service by 
March 25, 2025, 11:59 PM ET.
 Program is available only to legal US residents.
Price will be calculated at the time of 
2024
 tax return filing based on customer’s actual 2023 tax return prep fees minus 10%, or TurboTax’s current forms-based pricing, whichever is lowest, as determined by Sponsor in its sole discretion. The price difference will be adjusted at time of tax filing unless Sponsor requests proof of last year’s payment.
To receive this offer, customer must provide an eligible receipt for 2023 personal taxes (“Eligible Receipt”) upon TurboTax’s request. The Eligible Receipt must be a valid receipt as determined by TurboTax in its sole discretion. If customer does not provide an Eligible Receipt, customer will not be entitled to any discount or an alternative Full Service offer. In such event, customer may be prohibited from using Full Service to file customer’s 2024 taxes and may be transferred to another TurboTax service, as determined by TurboTax in its sole discretion.
Price includes 1 federal filing and applicable state filings via Full Service; other products or services are not included. Excludes TurboTax Full Service Business, TurboTax Verified Pro and TurboTax Canada services. Offer not available in combination with any other TurboTax offers and not valid for use with TurboTax self-preparation offerings. TurboTax reserves the right to modify or terminate this offer at any time for any reason in its sole discretion.

subject: Are workers making the most of their life insurance benefits?
body:
Helping employees make the connection between financial wellness and life insurance 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Webinar series
Did you know that, for most Americans, the life insurance they get through work is the only life insurance they own? Life insurance is more than just a policy – it's a crucial financial protection product. However, many workers don't fully understand the need for life insurance and the impact that it can have on financial wellness.  
 
Join us
 to discover the key role that group life insurance plays in workers’ financial wellness, how life insurance needs change throughout various life stages, how life insurance works with other products, and how to most effectively communicate all of this to workers.

subject: Special delivery: Your quarterly update on employee benefits is here
body:
Brush up on tips and best practices to help make the most of open enrollment — and boost utilization 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Benefits enrollment solutions
Here’s your Guardian Group Benefits Client Quarterly
It’s open enrollment season — here’s why enrollment matters.
According to Guardian’s Annual Workplace Benefits Study, 65% of employers feel very strongly that their benefit communications and enrollment process help workers make the best benefit decisions.
1
 
The issue? Only 39% of employees feel the same way, and need more help understanding their benefits.
1
This may signal the need for a different approach to benefit communications. 
Key resources to help empower you (and your employees) this enrollment season
Send 
5 things to check before making your annual benefits enrollment selection
 to your employees to help get them prepared for benefit elections
 
Post 
digital banners
 on your benefits site or in your benefit communications
 
Post our 
Simply Put video series
 (about life, disability, dental, critical illness, and hospital indemnity) on your benefit page or in other benefit communications
 
Share our 
life, oral health, and supplemental health quizzes
 to help engage and educate employees on these benefits
 
Review our 
life
, 
oral health
, and 
supplemental health
 education pages
 
Explore our 
deciding moments
 enrollment page that provides guidance and considerations based on life stage
If you submit enrollment data via EDI, 
download our Open Enrollment EDI FAQ
 for insights and tips for submitting the file.
 
What benefit communications challenges should employers like you consider?
 
With 63% of employers reporting that attracting and retaining talent is the biggest challenge they’ll face next year, overcoming challenges to 
benefits education and utilization will be crucial
.
2 
Here’s what employees are saying about their current experience:    
36% report spending no time researching benefit options
2
 
Only 22% feel extremely confident about their recent benefit selections
3
Why does having a benefit enrollment strategy matter?
Employees are
 
3x more confident
 with their benefit selections when they’re satisfied with enrollment.
4
 Additionally, workers who report satisfaction with their enrollment experience are 
2x more likely to stay at their company
 because of the benefits offered.
4
 
Looking for ways to help grab your employees' attention and increase engagement during enrollment? Consider leveraging these best practices:
Know your audience (what’s important to them, how they prefer to receive benefit information, etc.)
 
Establish a strategy with goals and act on employee feedback
 
Communicate benefits year-round
 
Test tools that engage and educate employees
 
Leverage brokers and carriers for support
Watch 
The Keys to Success: Best practices for benefits engagement
 for practical tips to leverage.
 
Benefit communications across five generations can be challenging, especially for employees who are early in their career. Our enrollment specialists debunk common misconceptions younger employees may have. 
 
Making the Right Connections: Helping younger employees make the right benefits choices
 is packed with examples and insights to help engage employees across generations.
When preparing your upcoming benefit communications, consider these best practices: 
Define your benefits enrollment goal to help take a measured approach
 
Start the discussion with stakeholders as early as possible
 
Understand the needs of your employee base and solicit their feedback
 
Involve leadership to gain support and show your commitment to helping employees understand and get the most out of their benefits
Watch 
Enrollment Case Studies: An inside look at how to optimize your enrollment strategy
 for more ideas and best practices. 
Guardian can help
 
Remember, we’re here to help you. Contact your Guardian representative for assistance on leveraging our 
available tools
 to help support your benefit communication and enrollment needs.
P.S. As you begin your 2025 planning process, review our 
latest report
 on digital benefit trends revolution, for things to consider for your technology planning.
 
1
“
The Keys to Success: Best practices for driving benefits engagement
,” aired 7/10/24.
2
 13
th
 Annual Guardian Workplace Benefits Study, 2024. The Guardian 13th Annual Workplace Benefits Study was fielded in January and February of 2024 and consisted of two online surveys: one among benefits decision-makers (employers) and another among working Americans (employees), allowing us to explore benefits issues from both perspectives. 
3 
Benefits Optimization 2023: How supplemental health benefits and omnichannel communications support workforce well-being, 12th Annual Guardian Workplace Benefits Study, 2023
4

 Annual Guardian Workplace Benefits Study, 2024

body:

Webinar series
Paid leave is rapidly evolving. Not only has the continued lack of a national paid leave approach prompted many states to pass their own laws, but several employers are also expanding their own leave offerings. In addition, there’s been a trend toward greater integration of an employer’s leave program with benefits that support employee well-being. subject: How employers can help employees overcome the tobacco habit
body:
Tobacco usage and its impact on workforce well-being 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Read our report
Our latest study shows that while tobacco use is declining in the US, almost a third of working Americans use tobacco products. The good news? Workers want help quitting. In fact, 66% of them would be very interested in using a tobacco cessation program through their dental insurance plan if it came at no additional cost. This is especially true for workers whose children may also use tobacco products, especially e-cigarettes. Organizations would benefit, too, by retaining a healthier, more productive workforce and lower medical claims costs.
 
A few of the findings: 
60% of smokeless tobacco users say that if they knew the products harmed their oral health, they would consider quitting.
 
82% of workers with a child who uses tobacco would be interested in a tobacco cessation program if the program were available to dependents.
 
Cigarette smokers take an average of over 7 more days of sick leave per year compared to non-smokers.
Expanding benefits programs to include support for tobacco cessation can be important for oral, physical, and mental health. 
Download the report
 
to discover how to find the right solutions. 
 
 
Explore Guardian Edge
 
Get the latest workplace benefits insights with a variety of content — including articles, checklists, reports, and more — to help support all stages of your employees' journeys. 
Visit Guardian Edge
.
 
Unless otherwise noted, all data is sourced from Guardian’s 13th Annual Workplace Benefits Study, 2024.
 
For broker/agent use only.

body:

View this email as a web page

Webinar series
The number of employers offering mental health benefits to their workforce has more than doubled since 2016. But with American workers’ self-reported mental health still declining, and with many saying they don’t seek out mental health care because they can’t afford it, there’s more to be done. Fortunately, supporting mental wellness in the workplace is mutually beneficial for both employers and workers alike, as research shows that providing mental health resources can improve employee engagement, productivity, and even contribute to a positive return on investment (ROI).

subject: How do key life moments affect your employees’ well-being?
body:
Read our latest report to find out 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Read our report
Our latest report shows that working Americans’ well-being is lower than in past years. Contributing to this decline is a lack of control workers feel about the economy. In fact, 
money is the top source of stress in employees’ lives
, with half concerned their retirement savings won’t last as long as they need it to.    
 
The new research also reveals that this sense of uncertainty can be magnified during major life moments — such as having a child, confronting a serious health diagnosis, or becoming a caregiver. As an employer, you have the chance to better support employees during these critical times. Find out which benefits and well-being initiatives can help you support your employees.

subject: Helping employees quit tobacco use
body:
People who smoke have a 10x higher risk for oral cancer compared to nonsmokers 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Webinar series
The use of tobacco in products like cigarettes, e-cigarettes, and chewing tobacco is linked to problems with oral — and overall — health. People who smoke have a 10x higher risk for oral cancer compared to nonsmokers,
1
 and at least 28 cancer-causing chemicals have been found in smokeless tobacco products.
2
 Not only can these conditions lead to workforce health problems and associated higher claims costs, tobacco use is linked to lower confidence and work performance.
3
  
 
Join us
 as our speakers discuss how employers can provide tobacco cessation benefits and support programs to reduce tobacco-related risk among their workers and promote better oral and overall health.

subject: Open now to explore how you can help support your employees and their loved ones
body:
You don't often get email from guardian_employee_benefits@glic.com. 
Learn why this is important
Because an event, accident, or illness may take any employee away from work 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Group Disability Insurance
Here’s your Guardian Group Benefits Client Quarterly
May is Disability Insurance Awareness Month.
As an HR professional, you likely know the important role that 
disability insurance
 plays in helping provide financial protection to employees if an illness, accident, or other event like maternity keeps them out of work. But many employees may not make this connection, and fail to protect their income the way they protect other things that are innately important to them — health, home, and family.
By shedding light on some of the misconceptions around disability insurance, workers are able to help better protect themselves and employers are able to help better protect their workforces. Use these resources to understand how to help your employees protect their finances, and the role disability insurance plays in their overall well-being:
Download the disability insurance facts and figures report
 
Download the group disability insurance overview flyer
Resources to share with employees:
 
Share the 4 myths about disability insurance article
 
Share the short-term disability insurance Simply Put video
 
Share the long-term disability insurance Simply Put video
 
Employees may underestimate their chances of experiencing an income-disrupting event
 
While 92% of employees are concerned about being financially prepared if one of their household's primary wage earners should become unable to work due to an illness or injury, most people still tend to adopt a “not me” mindset and underestimate their need for disability benefits.
1
Here’s why that mindset can raise concerns
People of all ages, demographics, and professions have roughly the same potential to experience an income-disrupting injury, illness, or condition. In fact, 
25% of today’s 20-year-olds
 will take a disability-related leave before reaching retirement age.
2
 And 30% of US households have had a main wage earner experience at least one injury, illness, or condition that resulted in either a short-term disability (STD) or long-term disability (LTD) leave sometime in the past 10 years.
3
Leading causes of disability claims:
Disability insurance covers a lot more than your employees might realize. Here are the leading causes of disability claims:
4
STD
Maternity
Musculoskeletal (non-back)
Injury (non-back)
Mental and nervous conditions
LTD
Cancer
Musculoskeletal (non-back)
Circulatory
Back
How employers can help:
 
Disability insurance offered through work can play a significant role in helping provide access to financial protection against loss of income due to a disability. On average, 38% of employers pay the full cost of their disability benefit plans, 47% share the cost with workers, and 17% offer employee-pay-all or voluntary disability coverage.
5
Other support for employees facing a possible disability leave
Taking a disability leave may be stressful for employees. These mental wellness resources can help them better manage any challenges they may face:
Discover workplace mental wellness resources and insights
 
Read the employer guide to recognizing and preventing employee burnout
 
Share the Take a Breath exercise video
 
Share this article with 5 helpful stress management techniques
Webinar replay — in case you missed it:
 
Our “A smooth transition: supporting mental health during and after a disability leave” webinar includes an overview with tips on supporting the mental health of employees before, during, and after a disability leave — so they have the resources to take on whatever they’re facing. 
Watch now
 
1,2,3,4,5 
Insuring Your Income: The role of disability insurance in financial wellness
, Guardian 12th Annual Workplace Benefits Study, 2023.
Guardian’s Group Short and Long Term Disability Insurance is underwritten and issued by The Guardian Life Insurance Company of America, New York, NY. Products are not available in all states.

subject: The 2023 Guardian Annual: A whole different perspective
body:
You don't often get email from guardian_employee_benefits@glic.com.

In The Guardian Annual, you will see how our investments and innovations impact our customers at critical moments in their lives 
View this email as a web page 
here
I’m proud to share 
The 2023 Guardian Annual
, which focuses on how we work hard to 
inspire well-being
®
 in everything we do and with every decision we make.  
 
Guardian’s proprietary research
1
 shows less than half of employees say their benefits meet all of their needs. So, we have worked to further enrich the lives of our members by expanding our products and services to include mental wellness benefits, a new dental plan for children under 12, and more robust benefits features for those embarking on family planning. And we know that new parents don’t need to deal with the stress of reduced income. We offer the option to waive the typical waiting period on maternity claims and provide access to disability benefits from day one.
 
In 
The Guardian Annual
, you will see how our investments and innovations impact our customers at critical moments in their lives. You will also find stories of people whose lives have been improved through Guardian and who demonstrate how our approach to providing benefits inspire well-being.   
 
One of those profiles is of Dr. Jian Lee at Cumberland Valley Pediatric Dentistry. A Guardian network provider, Dr. Lee shares  our commitment to helping children establish good oral health habits at an early age because of the long-term well-being benefits. That’s why Guardian’s Early Smiles plan covers 100% of dental care for children 12 years and under, helping parents remove a financial barrier to care, encouraging kids’ overall well-being, and building a life-long patient-doctor rapport.
2
 
Thank you for continuing to place your trust in us.
 
Sincerely,
Michael Prestileo
Chief Commercial Officer

subject: How EAPs can support holistic well-being
body:
You don't often get email from guardianedge@glic.com. 
Learn why this is important
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Webinar series
Employee assistance programs (EAPs) give workers access to highly professional, confidential resources for personal concerns like mental health, caregiving responsibilities, and even work-life balance. But workers may be unaware of what EAPs include — or have misconceptions around confidentiality, cost, and access that can keep them from fully exploring a wealth of resources that could help them in times of stress, difficulty, or future planning.
 
Join us
 as our speakers explore ways that employers can broaden awareness around the value of EAPs and encourage their workers to reap the benefits.
12–1 pm ET Wednesday, February 28, 2024
 
Related content
 
Mind, Body, and Wallet™ 2023: Economic challenges and uncertainty take a toll on well-being
Guardian’s 12th Annual Workplace Benefits Study shows the lowest level of overall well-being among Americans since the inception of this study. The report examines how workers feel about their mental, physical, and financial health, the factors contributing to it, and some insights into which workplace well-being initiatives could help organizations prepare for the future.
 
10 ways to help improve your mental health and well-being
When it comes to overall well-being, physical and mental health go hand in hand. Poor mental health can lead to physical health problems,
1
 and positive mental health can help limit physical health issues.
2
 That's why overall health means caring for your body and your mind.
 
Mental wellness in the workplace
Employees need more support as they deal with unprecedented work and life stress — but the approaches to care we are used to through medical or ancillary benefits may not be enough. You can empower employees to think, feel, and perform their best by offering intuitive mental wellness support through your benefits.

subject: Read now: How you can help employees and their families
body:
Ensure they know how to use their dental benefits in support of good oral health 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
 
, here’s your Guardian Group Benefits Client Quarterly
February is National Children’s Dental Health Month.
Enabling good oral health for employees and their families matters – this month, and beyond. The connection between oral health and overall well-being is too important not to support. That’s why Guardian offers dependent dental coverage that helps families save — a big deal since oral health is an important part of a child's total health care.
Use these resources to help employees understand how their benefits can help build and maintain good oral health for the whole family:
Watch the Oral Health Webinar Series
 
Download preventive dentistry and oral health report
Resources to share with employees:
Download the oral health tips for parents flyer
 
Get the coloring book, complete with kid-friendly oral health tips
You can also access all of these resources and more online.
 
 
How we help you protect company and employee data
 
Just as we’re committed to supporting you as you help employees and families protect their oral health and wellness, we’re also committed to helping you protect company and employee data.
 
Here’s how:
The Authorized Approver of Access (AAA):
 This is a person your company designates to manage and grant access to your company’s information on Guardian Anytime. This person approves additional users, removes users who leave the company, and can change user roles and statuses. It’s an important job — but we’re here to help you every step of the way. 
Download the guide
The way we protect employee personal information:
 
You can provide either a company-issued employee ID or social security number when submitting employee enrollment data. Either way, we secure the information in Guardian’s system and NEVER use this information to identify employees. Instead, we use your group number, employee name, date of birth, address, or the assigned Guardian member ID. 
Employees can help protect data, too – and you can help
.
Give employees easy access to your group number for registration.
 
Encourage employees to register on Guardian Anytime to access benefit info, submit and review claims, and access their dental and/or vision cards, if applicable. 
Download the flyer to share with employees
Webinar replay - in case you missed it:
 
Guardian Anytime Service Portal Webinar: 
We put together a quick webinar that walks you through the ways you can make the most of Guardian Anytime for simpler benefits management. 
Watch now

body:
You don't often get email from guardianedge@glic.com. 
Learn why this is important
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Webinar series
Thirty-one years after it was enacted, many employers still misunderstand the Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA) of 1993. The fundamentals of the FMLA proved to be more complicated than anticipated, and employers report that it is now more
difficult than in previous years to approve leaves and coordinate leave types.
1
 
Join us
 as our speakers provide an overview of FMLA basics, including rules around eligibility, roles and responsibilities, common errors, and opportunities to test your knowledge of the law.
12–1 pm ET Wednesday, February 21, 2024
 
Related content
 
The Value of Leave Integration: Coordinating benefits plans and leave policies contributes to improved outcomes
Read Guardian's report to learn what to prioritize in your absence management and integration program.
 
Family and Medical Leave Act Quiz
How well do you know the fundamentals? Find out by taking this short quiz and exploring additional resources to strengthen your understanding.
 
Tips to improve the employee leave practice
 
A robust employee leave program that simplifies the leave experience can be an essential part of an employee-focused benefits suite. Read more for tips to help promote a smooth leave experience for your employees.

subject: Better children’s oral health -> better workforce well-being in 2024?
body:
You don't often get email from guardian_employee_benefits@glic.com. 
Learn why this is important
Learn the impact children’s dental care can have on your workforce. And help. 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Children's dental health
3 reasons children’s oral health and dental care matter
1.
On average, 34 million school hours are missed each year because of major or unplanned dental care.
1
Why it matters:
 That means parents can’t work either. 
Learn how to help
.
2.
Nearly 9 in 10 parents say their children’s oral health is important and generally they prioritize their children’s oral health above their own.
2
Why it matters:
 You can show your employees they are valued by supporting what they care about.
Go to #3
This Children’s Dental Health Month, 
get the tools and resources
 – fun ones like a coloring book – to help families establish a lifetime of good oral health habits. And ensure the benefits you offer make it easy for kids to get dental care. There are multiple payoffs.
 
1
 
CDC.gov, Division of Oral Health, National Center for Chronic Disease Prevention and Health Promotion
, January, 2021
 
2

subject: Register Now: Helping kids build good oral health habits
body:
You don't often get email from guardianedge@glic.com. 
Learn why this is important
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Webinar series
Kids’ oral health practices can impact families' daily lives — in more ways than one. For example, the CDC reports that, on average, 34 million school hours are lost each year to emergency dental care.
1
 And when a kid is at the dentist, their parent may be missing work. This is just one reason why encouraging positive oral health habits in kids, like visiting the dentist regularly, can help set them — and the next generation of workers — up for a lifetime of better oral health and overall lower dental costs.  
 
In recognition of National Children’s Dental Health Month, hear from our speakers on how to help employees engage their kids on the topic of oral health, choosing dental plans with strong pediatric benefits, and how improving dental coverage for employees’ dependents can go a long way toward helping organizations keep dental costs down.  
12–1 pm ET Wednesday, February 14, 2024
 
Related content
 
Chew on this: 5 ways your oral health is connected to your overall health
 
Did you know that good oral health is also connected to your overall well-being? Learn about the range of positive health benefits that your body will thank you for if you’re on top of your dental hygiene. 
 
An oral health quiz for your dental fundamentals
 
Oral health issues are among the most common — and the most preventable — health concerns impacting the American public. Take this short quiz to discover your level of knowledge about dental care. 
 
Dental Fundamentals: In-demand benefits that support well-being
 
The last few years have brought renewed consumer appreciation for dental benefits. Our latest research reveals the most in-demand dental plan options for businesses to consider. 
 
The connection between oral health and overall health
 
 
Oral health is an integral part of your overall well-being. Find out how they're related and what you can do to promote a healthy mouth and body.

Visit Guardian Edge

subject: NEW Report: Is your organization doing enough to support caregiving employees?
body:
You don't often get email from guardianedge@glic.com. 
Learn why this is important
While there’s been a sharp rise in employees acting as unpaid family caregivers while working full time 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
 
While there’s been a sharp rise in employees acting as unpaid family caregivers while working full time, our latest report finds that fewer than half of workers have communicated about their caregiving responsibilities with their managers. 
 
Tell me more
.
Our latest research finds:
41% of caregivers report low overall well-being — that’s 32% more than non-caregivers.
 
Working caregivers are 2x as likely as non-caregivers to experience their own disability-related leave of absence.
 
Only 44% of caregivers say their benefits meet their needs, and 23% don’t think their employer cares about their overall well-being.
 
Explore Guardian Edge
 
Get the latest workplace benefits insights with a variety of content — including articles, checklists, reports, and more — to help support all stages of your employees' journeys. 
Visit Guardian Edge
.
 
Unless otherwise noted, all information contained in this message is from Guardian’s 12th Annual Workplace Benefits Study, 2024.

subject: Register Now: Why workers’ financial wellness has declined
body:
You don't often get email from guardianedge@glic.com. 
Learn why this is important
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Webinar series
Guardian research shows that the top three factors causing US workers the most stress are all finance-related — and this pressure has wider-reaching implications than a slim wallet. In fact, money-related pressures have an outsized impact on overall well-being, with recent dramatic declines in workers’ self-reported financial health contributing to lower rates of physical and emotional health, as well.
1
 
Join us
 
as our speakers discuss the financial challenges and opportunities facing US workers and their employers today, including the gap between workers’ financial intentions and their habits, macroeconomic developments that have led to the dramatic decline in financial health, and how employers can help improve workers’ financial habits by providing financial resources.
12–1 pm ET Wednesday, January 31, 2024
Register Now
 
Related content
 
Mind, Body, and Wallet™ 2023: Economic challenges and uncertainty take a toll on well-being
 
Guardian’s 12th Annual Workplace Benefits Study shows the lowest level of overall well-being among Americans since the inception of this study. The report examines how workers feel about their mental, physical, and financial health, the factors contributing to it, and some insights into which workplace well-being initiatives could help organizations prepare for the future, whatever it may bring.
 
Financial literacy for employees: Why it matters and how to help
Many employees say their physical and mental health have been impacted by financial worries. Employers can provide a high-value benefit by offering financial literacy programs to their workforce. It’s a strategy that may help improve the productivity and retention of current workers and attract top-level talent.
 
Four ways to financially empower your employees
Guardian financial representative Ivan Watanabe shares tips on providing financial and benefits guidance to employees.

subject: Register Now: A modern look at caregivers in the US
body:
You don't often get email from guardianedge@glic.com. 
Learn why this is important
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Webinar series
Forty-three percent more employees currently split their time between working and caregiving for loved ones than did just four years ago. On a macro scale, this puts a strain on the labor market that costs the US economy around $44 billion annually.
1
 On a personal level, this causes significant stress for the caregivers themselves.
 
 
Join us
 as our panel of speakers who are part of the “caregiving economy” share their unique perspectives on a variety of caregiving topics from work challenges and helpful policies and benefits, to what they wish employers knew about supporting caregiving workers.
12–1 pm ET Wednesday, January 24, 2024
Register Now
 
Related content
 
Standing Up and Stepping In: A modern look at caregivers in the US
Caregiving in America is on the rise. There’s significant room for improvement when it comes to how employers can better support caregivers and equip their workers to effectively care for their loved ones while having a productive experience at work. As demand for caregivers increases, employers can explore ways to better support caregivers and provide access to helpful benefits.
 
How employers can support caregivers coping with increased responsibilities
  
Employer support and workplace benefits that address caregivers’ needs are necessary for this growing segment of the US workforce. Here are strategies that employers can put in place to support caregivers.    
 
Video: Maintain structure for both caregivers and those in need of care
 
 
Annette Hammortree speaks about the importance of having structure when caring for someone. She offers insights to the critical role work can play in creating balance in someone’s life. In addition, she provides tips for employers to support employees who want to remain engaged.

body:
You don't often get email from guardianedge@glic.com.

View this email as a web page 
here
 
Webinar series
As 2024 begins, it’s an ideal time to think about reassessing your organization’s approach to benefits and culture to better support workers’ well-being, boost talent attraction and retention, and create a caring workplace culture.
 
Join us
 
to learn what employers need to know about the top trends driving benefits in 2024, from paid leave policy expansion to mental health — and how to better market benefits to employees.
12–1 pm ET Wednesday, January 17, 2024
Register Now
 
Related content
 
Mind, Body, and Wallet™ 2023: Economic challenges and uncertainty take a toll on well-being
 
Guardian’s 12th Annual Workplace Benefits Study shows the lowest level of overall well-being among Americans since the inception of this study. The report examines how workers feel about their mental, physical, and financial health, the factors contributing to it, and some insights into which workplace well-being initiatives could help organizations prepare for the future, whatever it may bring.
 
Tips to improve the employee leave practice
  
  
A robust employee leave program that simplifies the leave experience can be an essential part of an employee-focused benefits suite. Read more for tips to help promote a smooth leave experience for your employees.  
 
Managing the mental and emotional health of you and your workforce
 
According to the National Alliance in Mental Illness, each year, 1 in 5 US adults are affected by a mental health condition; more than half of them (55%) receive no treatment.¹ Help manage the mental and emotional health of you and your workforce with this resource. 
 
Benefits Optimization: How supplemental health benefits and omnichannel communications support workforce well-being 
 
The need for benefits that help employees protect both their financial and physical wellness is more important than ever. Learn what to prioritize in your supplemental health benefits program and how to communicate to employees during enrollment to set yourself up for success.

body:
You don't often get email from guardianedge@glic.com.

View this email as a web page 
here
 
Webinar series
For many, even thinking about money and managing personal finances can elicit feelings of anxiety and be overwhelming. This stress can be detrimental in all areas of life, especially at work.
 
Join us
 as our speaker discusses the roots and symptoms of financial anxiety and how employers can provide resources to their employees that can help shape better financial habits and boost confidence.

subject: Our latest workforce well-being content & insights
body:
You don't often get email from guardianedge@glic.com. 
Learn why this is important
Gain an edge in managing your workforce’s well-being 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
December 2023
Welcome to Guardian Edge, a resource for the latest articles, webinars, and workplace
insights from Guardian.
 
Americans’ overall well-being hits 12-year low 
Following a peak in self-reported well-being in 2022, our latest research finds employees rating their mental, physical, and financial wellness at record lows.
Mind, Body, and Wallet
TM
 2023: Economic challenges and uncertainty take a toll on well-being
With 40% of American workers living paycheck to paycheck, economic and personal finance-related concerns are contributing to a decline in overall health. This year’s report examines this and other recent trends across mental, physical, and financial wellness, illuminating which areas have changed the most and how employers are investing in their workforces.
 
Mind, Body, and Wallet
TM
 2023
 Webinar
For many Americans, access to wellness resources begins at work, so variety is key. In this webinar, a panel of HR and benefits leaders discuss the downturn in overall health and what employers can do to help meet employees’ growing financial and emotional wellness needs.
 
Resources for caregivers of every kind
Standing Up and Stepping In: A modern look at caregivers in the US
Did you know that only 22% of caregivers report high overall well-being? The number of working caregivers has risen to around 100 million, with workforce health and productivity continuously being impacted. Gain insight into what employers can do to help support these employees, alleviate stress, and offer more inclusive policies.
 
Do you see yourself as a caregiver? 
Many caregivers often don’t identify as one, though they could benefit from the resources a caregiver typically needs.
 
Helping the Helpers: A look at caregivers and how we can better serve them 
Roughly half of US adults care for a child, parent, or other relative, and most of them report low overall well-being. Learn how employers can aid caregiver employees in looking after their own health.
 
Special Needs Caregiving: Supporting a child with mental health and other challenges
Parents of children with special needs face unique challenges, but employers can offer resources to assist them.
 
Supporting employees’ mental wellness
Mental wellness benefits: Top trends you should know now
Understand what’s behind the growing need for mental wellness benefits in the workplace.
 
Coping with Chronic Medical Conditions: Support tools for better well-being
Gain tips for helping your workforce maintain healthy mental habits when living with a chronic condition.
 
Claiming Your Peace: Managing mental wellness around the holidays
The holidays can initiate or exacerbate mental health stressors, but there are techniques your employees can deploy to promote overall well-being.
 
Suicide prevention: Follow the ACE model
Spring Health’s Senior Director of Employer Strategy, Mandie Conforti, explains the three-part ACE model for suicide intervention: ask, care, encourage. 
 
Underscoring the critical impacts of disability insurance and paid leave
Insuring Your Income: The role of disability insurance in financial wellness
Disability insurance ownership has been trending down for a decade, though 25% percent of 20-year-olds will have to take a disability-related leave before reaching retirement age. Many don’t realize that disabilities often result from less severe injuries and conditions. Learn other common misconceptions surrounding this form of protection, as well as how it can help mitigate the financial effects of a disability.
 
Five steps employers can take today to keep pace with the leave management landscape
State and local paid family medical leave policies are becoming more complex. Review some of the tactics employers are leveraging to address their expansion, such as outsourcing and opt-out provisions. 
 
Guardian Honored with 2023 Disability
Matters Award
Guardian was recognized for its educational content that reinforces the importance of disability inclusion.
 
Critical Connections: Helping employees get the support they need following a cancer diagnosis
Provide reassurance and reduce stress for employees battling cancer and other serious illnesses by offering a full suite of benefits.
 
Guardian Edge: Bringing you insights on employee benefits trends, workforce well-being, and the workplace. 
 
Material discussed is meant for general informational purposes only. Guardian, its subsidiaries, agents, and employees do not provide tax, legal, medical, or financial advice. Consult your tax, legal, finance, or medical professional regarding your individual situation.

subject: What are the top benefits trends for 2024?
body:
You don't often get email from guardianedge@glic.com. 
Learn why this is important
As 2024 approaches, it’s an ideal time to think about reassessing your organization’s approach to benefits 
View this email as a web page 
here
 
Webinar series
As 2024 approaches, it’s an ideal time to think about reassessing your organization’s approach to benefits and culture to better support workers’ well-being, boost talent attraction and retention, and create a caring workplace culture.
 
Join us
 to learn what employers need to know about the top trends driving benefits in 2023, from paid leave policy expansion to mental health — and how to better market benefits to employees.
12–1 pm ET Wednesday, December 20, 2023
 
Related content
 
Mind, Body, and Wallet™ 2023: Economic challenges and uncertainty take a toll on well-being
 
Guardian’s 12th Annual Workplace Benefits Study shows the lowest level of overall well-being among Americans since the inception of this study. The report examines how workers feel about their mental, physical, and financial health, the factors contributing to it, and some insights into which workplace well-being initiatives could help organizations prepare for the future, whatever it may bring.
 
Tips to improve the employee leave practice
  
  
A robust employee leave program that simplifies the leave experience can be an essential part of an employee-focused benefits suite. Read more for tips to help promote a smooth leave experience for your employees.  
 
Managing the mental and emotional health of you and your workforce
 
According to the National Alliance in Mental Illness, each year, 1 in 5 US adults are affected by a mental health condition; more than half of them (55%) receive no treatment.¹ Help manage the mental and emotional health of you and your workforce with this resource.  
 
Benefits Optimization: How supplemental health benefits and omnichannel communications support workforce well-being 
 
The need for benefits that help employees protect both their financial and physical wellness is more important than ever. Learn what to prioritize in your supplemental health benefits program and how to communicate to employees during enrollment to set yourself up for success.  
 
Explore Guardian Edge
 
Get the latest workplace benefits insights with a variety of content — including articles, checklists, reports, and more — to help support all stages of your employees' journeys. 
 
Don’t miss a single webinar: 
Register for upcoming webinars and watch past webinars on demand
.
 
1. National Alliance on Mental Illness

subject: Tomorrow! Benefit Evolution – The Next Generation of Short-Term Disability, Workers Compensation, and PFML
body:
You don't often get email from groupbenefits@agent.thehartford.com. 
Learn why this is important
Sign-up for tomorrow’s 60-minute webinar
  
  
  
  
  
  
 
  
View as a webpage
 
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
Benefit Evolution – The Next Generation of Short‑Term Disability, Workers’ Compensation, and PFML 
  
Sign up today for our 60‑minute webinar 
  
 
Wednesday, November 29, 2023
 
12:00 p.m. – 1:00 p.m. EST
 
  
Sign Up Today 
  
  
  
  
  
  
The Hartford is excited to be sponsoring the Disability Management Employer Coalition (DMEC) webinar: 
Benefit Evolution – The Next Generation of Short‑Term Disability, Workers’ Compensation, and PFML
 on November 29th at 12:00p.m. EST. As a valued client, we are pleased to offer you complimentary registration for this event. 
  
Can short‑term disability (STD), workers’ compensation, and paid family and medical leave (PFML) coexist? Indeed, they can, and in fact, some states require it. These income protection provisions serve as vital safety nets – safeguarding employees’ physical, mental, and financial health. If PFML is heading to your state, it may look different than you think. An increasing number of states are introducing optional PFML programs, providing employers with greater flexibility. Additionally, short‑term disability policies are undergoing transformations. When combined with workers’ compensation, it results in a comprehensive support program. 
  
In this webinar, you’ll learn more about: 
  
• 
  
The changing leave landscape and what it means for your state. 
  
• 
  
The connection between STD and workers’ compensation, return‑to‑work programs, and ADA accommodations. 
  
• 
  
Explore STD plans and the evolving options for both PFML and short‑term disability. 
  
• 
  
Gain insight into the advantages of program integration. 
  
  
  
 
  
This webinar is complimentary for The Hartford clients. When registering, 
enter 23HARTFORD1
 on the final step of the registration process to receive your registration. Learn more and register now. 
  
Register Now 
  
  
  
 
  
Meet The Keynote Speaker 
  
  
 
  
Megan Holstein, Head of Absence Management, Group Benefits, The Hartford 
  
Megan is the head of absence management for The Hartford. A nationally known authority in employment law and leave solutions, Megan oversees the strategic design and marketing of The Hartford’s absence management, disability and accommodations products. She has authored numerous articles and presented nationally on topics relating to employee benefits, absence management and technology solutions.

Sharon Andrus 
Head of Paid Family & Medical Leave, The Hartford

subject: Benefit Evolution – The Next Generation of Short-Term Disability, Workers Compensation, and PFML
body:
You don't often get email from groupbenefits@mail.thehartford.com. 
Learn why this is important
Sign-up for our 60-minute webinar
  
  
  
  
  
  
 
  
View as a webpage
 
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
Benefit Evolution – The Next Generation of Short‑Term Disability, Workers’ Compensation, and PFML 
  
Sign up today for our 60‑minute webinar 
  
 
Wednesday, November 29, 2023
 
12:00 p.m. – 1:00 p.m. EST
 
  
Sign Up Today 
  
  
  
  
  
  
The Hartford is excited to be sponsoring the Disability Management Employer Coalition (DMEC) webinar: 
Benefit Evolution – The Next Generation of Short‑Term Disability, Workers’ Compensation, and PFML
 on November 29th at 12:00p.m. EST. As a valued client, we are pleased to offer you complimentary registration for this event. 
  
Can short‑term disability (STD), workers’ compensation, and paid family and medical leave (PFML) coexist? Indeed, they can, and in fact, some states require it. These income protection provisions serve as vital safety nets – safeguarding employees’ physical, mental, and financial health. If PFML is heading to your state, it may look different than you think. An increasing number of states are introducing optional PFML programs, providing employers with greater flexibility. Additionally, short‑term disability policies are undergoing transformations. When combined with workers’ compensation, it results in a comprehensive support program. 
  
In this webinar, you’ll learn more about: 
  
• 
  
The changing leave landscape and what it means for your state. 
  
• 
  
The connection between STD and workers’ compensation, return‑to‑work programs, and ADA accommodations. 
  
• 
  
Explore STD plans and the evolving options for both PFML and short‑term disability. 
  
• 
  
Gain insight into the advantages of program integration. 
  
  
  
 
  
This webinar is complimentary for The Hartford clients. When registering, 
enter 23HARTFORD1
 on the final step of the registration process to receive your registration. Learn more and register now. 
  
Register Now 
  
  
  
 
  
Meet The Keynote Speaker 
  
  
 
  
Megan Holstein, Head of Absence Management, Group Benefits, The Hartford 
  
Megan is the head of absence management for The Hartford. A nationally known authority in employment law and leave solutions, Megan oversees the strategic design and marketing of The Hartford’s absence management, disability and accommodations products. She has authored numerous articles and presented nationally on topics relating to employee benefits, absence management and technology solutions. 
  
  
  
Meet the Speakers 
  
 
  
Sharon Andrus 
Head of Paid Family & Medical Leave, The Hartford 
  
  
 
  
Paul Dube 
Director, Disability Products, The Hartford 
  
  
 
  
Alison Scaia 
Head of Health Services, The Hartford

subject: Why The IRS Is Suspending ERTC Claims
body:
What this means for you and your small business.
  
View Online 
  
  
 
  
 
  
  
  
  
IRS Suspends Processing of ERTC Claims: What You Need to Know 
  
  
  
The IRS recently stopped processing Employee Retention Tax Credit. Find out what that means from Gene Marks. 
  
  
Learn More
 
  
  
  
A Note From Our Partner: 
  
Our partners at Accelerate Tax remain dedicated to helping small businesses through the ERC submission process. Accelerate Tax emphasizes that understanding and navigating IRS eligibility criteria requires significant expertise and diligence, which they strive to maintain. While no changes have been made to the ERC parameters or overall program, there is a clear shift in the IRS's processing timeframe. Rest assured, while there might be a shift in processing dynamics, they do not anticipate any significant disruption to clients. For more information, please 
reach out to Accelerate Tax.

subject: In Case You Missed It! PFML Trends Replay
body:
Adapting to Change: How Businesses Can Embrace PFML Trends
  
  
  
  
  
  
 
  
 
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
Now Available: Adapting to Change: How Businesses Can Embrace PFML Trends
 
  
Watch Replay 
  
  
  
  
  
  
Across the country, an increasing number of states are establishing Paid Family & Medical Leave programs. This means greater opportunity for employees, more options for employers, but also new administrative challenges... 
  
In this webinar replay we discuss: 
  
• 
  
The changing leave landscape and what it means for your state and industry 
  
• 
  
Evolving options for both PFML and short‑term disability benefits 
  
• 
  
Solving for gaps and optimizing income protection for your employees 
  
• 
  
Effective strategies for streamlining Absence Management 
  
We understand how complex leave administration can be for employers. That’s why The Hartford stays on top of new and updated leave laws around the country to help bring you the latest solutions and strategies in absence management.

subject: Announcing the Thank You Awards Podcast Exclusively on Spotify!
body:
Hear the stories of the Thank You Small Business Award Winners
 
 
 
 
View as a webpage 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hear the stories of the Thank You Small Business Award Winners.
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hey there!
 
  
Last summer marked the launch of the Thank You Small Business Awards. The Hartford is proud to have been a founding partner along with Spotify and Silver Lining. 
  
Today, we announce the Thank You Small Business Podcast, available exclusively on Spotify. Each episode features a different Winner who shares their individual story of vision, resilience, innovation, adaptability, and the commitment to using their businesses to create impact for their families, teams, communities, and the economy. 
  
  
🎧 Start Listening to 
Your First Episode Now! 
  
 
 
 
 
 
  
The Series is co‑hosted by Carissa Reiniger (Founder and CEO, Silver Lining), Rochelle Sanchirico (Global Head of Scaled Marketing and SMB Marketing, Spotify), and our very own Jon Aidukonis (Co‑Host of The Small Biz Ahead Podcast). 
 
 
 
 
Join us as we celebrate the Thank you Small Business Award Winners and don’t forget to share the episodes! We hope you enjoy hearing these incredible stories as much as we did!

subject: How are you? LCW is curious to hear your opinion!
body:
Based upon your feedback, opinion and ideas we can create a positive working atmosphere together.
May we ask you a few questions?
 
SHARE YOUR OPINION!
 
More about the theme mood
 
Emotions drive our actions and thoughts. Your mood during work can determine how you handle stressful situations, how productive you are and how well you perform. Moods can also trigger (positive or negative) behaviors of co-workers! Therefore it is important for your team or organization to receive regular (anonymous) feedback about how you feel at work and why. In this way they can contribute to your job satisfaction and a positive working climate. 
Thanks in advance!

subject: A message from BILL CEO and Founder
body:
An update on our response to the Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) events.
  
 
 
 
Dear valued customers,
I wanted to update you on our response to the Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) events. Our top priority is to support our customers. In the days since events unfolded, we have been processing pending transactions, and I'm happy to report that all SVB-related outstanding payments have been processed, and we're fully back to business as usual for payment processing.
On Monday, we announced 
new programs
 to help customers stay operational, including BILL balance, Divvy, BILL Pay by Card, invoice financing for your vendors on the BILL network, and extended payment terms for Divvy account holders impacted by SVB.
We have scaled up our support capabilities to meet increased demand and are here to help. If your business needs support, please don't hesitate to 
contact us
.
Thank you to those who have provided open communication and feedback during this stressful time. We value your trust and transparent partnerships. The BILL team will continue to work hard every day to honor that trust.
René

subject: Tornado Preparedness Week: How You Can Prepare
body:
Tornado Preparedness week is March 6th-10th
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
 
  
View as a webpage
 
  
  
  
  
  
  
 
 
 
 
 
Tornado Prepardeness Week
 
MARCH 6TH – 10TH
 
 
  
  
  
  
As we approach Tornado Preparedness week, our customers' safety is top of mind. Here are some important steps you can take to help you prepare ahead of tornado season. 
  
 
  
Identify a Safe Room 
  
  
When a tornado strikes, there's often very little time to react. A windowless area on the lowest floor in your home or business designed to withstand high winds and flying debris can help keep yourself and others safe during the storm. 
  
 
  
Know the Warning Signs 
  
  
If you see any of these signs, it could indicate a tornado is forming: 
  
  
• 
Dark, greenish sky 
  
• 
Large hail 
  
• 
Large, dark, low‑lying cloud (particularly if rotating) 
  
• 
Loud roar, similar to a freight train 
  
 
  
Seek Shelter 
  
  
Find the safest place possible, wherever you may be. Put as many walls and ceilings between yourself and the tornado as you can. If you're not near a building, get into your car, buckle the seatbelt, and cover your head with your arms. 
  
 
 
 
We’re here to help.
 For more on how you can prepare and what to do during and after a tornado, visit our 
Tornado Safety page
 at 
thehartford.com/heretohelp
. And as always, if and when you need us, our exceptional claim professionals stand ready to assist. 
 
 
 
  
Thank you for your business. 
  
 
Mary Nasenbenny
Chief Claims Officer

A working capital ratio of between 1.5 and 2.0 indicates your business is in good financial health.
  
View Online 
  
  
 
  
 
  
  
  
  
Working Capital: What It Is, Why It’s Important, and How to Increase It 
  
  
  
Like cash flow, your working capital is a useful tool for gauging your business’s financial health.
